subject: polity
title: Emergency Provisions - Part XVIII (Art 352-360)
description: Comprehensive comparison of three types of emergencies with constitutional provisions, effects, historical instances, and safeguards

rows.nationalEmergency: **Art 352** - Emergency due to War, External Aggression, Armed Rebellion
rows.stateEmergency:
**Art 356** - Failure of constitutional machinery in State

*[Detailed coverage in Centre-State Relations → Administrative]*
rows.financialEmergency: **Art 360** - Threat to financial stability or credit of India

rows.nationalEmergency:
**Three grounds**:
• War (actual war declared)
• External aggression (threat of war from foreign country)
• Armed rebellion (internal - 44th Amendment changed 'internal disturbance' to 'armed rebellion')

**44th Amendment**: Made grounds more specific; 'Internal disturbance' too vague, misused in 1975
rows.stateEmergency:
**One ground**:
• Government of State **cannot be carried on in accordance with Constitution**

**In practice**: Hung Assembly, loss of majority, Governor's report, law & order breakdown, corruption (often misused)

**S.R. Bommai (1994)**: Curbed misuse; Justiciable; Floor test mandatory
rows.financialEmergency:
**One ground**:
• Financial stability or credit of India (or any part) **threatened**

**Never proclaimed**: Not used even once since 1950

**Potential situations**: Economic collapse, debt default, currency crisis, bankruptcy

rows.nationalEmergency:
**President** on advice of Council of Ministers

**44th Amendment**: Advice must be **in writing**; President can ask Cabinet to reconsider once (but bound by reconsidered advice)
rows.stateEmergency:
**President** on receiving **Governor's report** or otherwise satisfied (suo motu)

**S.R. Bommai**: President's satisfaction **justiciable**; Courts can examine material basis
rows.financialEmergency: **President** on advice of Council of Ministers

rows.nationalEmergency:
**Within 1 month** of proclamation

**Both Houses** must approve by **special majority**:
• Majority of total membership of House
• 2/3 majority of members present and voting

**44th Amendment**: Earlier simple majority; Now special majority (harder to proclaim)
rows.stateEmergency:
**Within 2 months** of proclamation

**Both Houses** must approve by **simple majority**

**Easier than National Emergency**: Simple majority sufficient
rows.financialEmergency:
**Within 2 months** of proclamation

**Both Houses** must approve by **simple majority**

rows.nationalEmergency:
**Initially**: 6 months (if approved by Parliament)

**Extensions**: Can be extended **indefinitely** by 6 months at a time (each extension needs Parliamentary approval by special majority)

**Maximum**: No maximum limit

**1975-77 Emergency**: Lasted 21 months
rows.stateEmergency:
**Initially**: 6 months (if approved)

**Maximum**: **3 years** total

**Extension beyond 1 year** requires:
• National Emergency in force (Art 352), OR
• Election Commission certifies elections cannot be held

**44th Amendment**: Added these safeguards
rows.financialEmergency:
**No maximum duration** specified

**Indefinite**: Can continue as long as Parliament approves

**Never used**: No precedent

rows.nationalEmergency:
**By President** anytime (no Parliamentary approval needed for revocation)

**44th Amendment**: **Lok Sabha can disapprove** by simple majority → President MUST revoke

**Special provision**: If 1/10th of LS members give written notice → LS must meet within 14 days to consider disapproval resolution
rows.stateEmergency:
**By President** anytime (no Parliamentary approval needed for revocation)

**In practice**: Revoked when new govt formed after elections or confidence restored
rows.financialEmergency:
**By President** anytime (no Parliamentary approval needed for revocation)

**Never proclaimed**: No precedent of revocation

rows.nationalEmergency:
**Union executive power extends** to giving directions to States on any matter (Art 353)

**State govt continues**: State govts NOT dismissed (unlike Art 356)

**Centre controls**: But Centre can give binding directions; State autonomy reduced
rows.stateEmergency:
**State govt dismissed**: CM and Ministers resign/removed

**Governor rules**: On behalf of President

**Union takes over**: President exercises all powers of State govt + Governor
rows.financialEmergency:
**Union can direct States**:
• Observe financial propriety canons
• Reserve Money Bills/Financial Bills for President's consideration

**Salaries reduced**: Union can direct reduction of salaries of State employees (including HC judges)

rows.nationalEmergency:
**Parliament can legislate on State List** (Art 250)

**Duration**: Laws continue for **6 months** after emergency ends (then lapse)

**Parliament supremacy**: Parliament's law overrides State law
rows.stateEmergency:
**State Legislature**: Dissolved or kept in suspended animation (President's discretion)

**Parliament legislates**: Parliament can make laws for State (on State List subjects)

**Duration**: Laws continue even after emergency ends (don't lapse)
rows.financialEmergency:
**Union can direct**: States to reserve Money Bills for President's consideration

**Financial control**: Union controls State's financial legislation

rows.nationalEmergency:
**Art 358** (Automatic suspension):
• If emergency due to **war or external aggression** → Art 19 (6 freedoms) **automatically suspended**
• State can make any law violating Art 19
• No judicial remedy during emergency
• After emergency ends: Laws made during emergency continue (don't automatically become void)

**Art 359** (Presidential order suspension):
• President can suspend **right to move court** for enforcement of FRs (except Art 20, 21)
• **44th Amendment**: Art 20, 21 **CANNOT be suspended** (life & liberty protected even during emergency)
• President's order specifies which FRs suspended

**Armed Rebellion**: Only Art 359 applicable (Art 358 NOT applicable)
rows.stateEmergency:
**NO effect on FRs**

Fundamental Rights remain in force

**Citizens can approach courts** for FR violations
rows.financialEmergency:
**NO effect on FRs**

Fundamental Rights remain in force

**Citizens can approach courts** for FR violations

rows.nationalEmergency:
**Federal → Unitary**

• Parliament can legislate on State List
• Union can direct States
• Centre's financial control over States
• State autonomy curtailed

**BUT**: States NOT dismissed; Govts continue functioning under Centre's directions
rows.stateEmergency:
**Federal structure suspended** in that State

• State govt dismissed
• Parliament legislates for State
• Union rules State
• State becomes Union Territory-like

**Temporary**: Federal structure restored after emergency revoked
rows.financialEmergency:
**Federal → Unitary** (financial sphere)

• Union controls States' finances
• States' financial autonomy lost
• Union can reduce State employees' salaries

rows.nationalEmergency:
**3 times** (6 proclamations):

**1. 1962-68** (China war - Oct 1962)
**2. 1971-77** (Pakistan war - Dec 1971; continued)
**3. 1975-77** (Internal disturbance/'Emergency' - June 1975)

**1975 Emergency**: Most controversial; 'Internal disturbance' misused; 21 months; Suspended democracy
rows.stateEmergency:
**Used 125+ times** (most controversial)

**Frequently misused**: Political reasons, dismissing Opposition-ruled states

**Pre-Bommai** (before 1994): Very frequent (90+ times till 2000)

**Post-Bommai** (after 1994): Much less frequent; Judicial scrutiny reduced misuse

**Last used**: Arunachal Pradesh (2016), Uttarakhand (2016), J&K (2018)
rows.financialEmergency:
**NEVER used** (0 times)

Not proclaimed even once since 1950

**No precedent**: Provisions untested

rows.nationalEmergency:
**Pre-Emergency safeguards**:
• **Special majority** required (not simple majority)
• Cabinet advice must be **in writing**
• President can ask Cabinet to reconsider
• **'Armed rebellion'** (not vague 'internal disturbance')

**During Emergency**:
• Art 20, 21 **CANNOT be suspended** (life & liberty protected)
• LS can disapprove by simple majority → President must revoke
• 1/10th LS members can demand meeting for disapproval

**Post-Emergency**:
• Laws made violating Art 19 continue (but can be challenged after emergency)
rows.stateEmergency:
**44th Amendment safeguards**:
• Duration limited to **3 years max** (earlier indefinite)
• Extension beyond 1 year needs National Emergency OR EC certification

**Judicial safeguards** (S.R. Bommai 1994):
• **Justiciable** - Courts can review
• **Floor test mandatory** - If majority dispute, prove on Assembly floor
• President must independently assess (not blindly follow Governor)
• **Federalism is basic structure** - Cannot be arbitrarily destroyed
rows.financialEmergency:
**No specific safeguards** in Constitution

**Parliamentary approval**: Needs Parliamentary approval within 2 months

**Revocable**: President can revoke anytime

**Never used**: No judicial precedent

rows.nationalEmergency:
**1975 Emergency**: Biggest criticism
• Democracy suspended 21 months
• Press censorship, mass arrests, FR suspended
• Indira Gandhi govt misused 'internal disturbance'
• Opposition leaders jailed, judiciary weakened

**44th Amendment response**: Tightened provisions to prevent future misuse

**Grounds too wide**: Even 'armed rebellion' can be misused
rows.stateEmergency:
**Most controversial provision**:
• Used 125+ times; Often for **political reasons**
• Centre dismissing Opposition-ruled states (1977-79, 1980s-90s)
• Undermines federalism, democratic process
• Governor's partisan reports

**S.R. Bommai (1994)**: Judicial intervention curbed misuse significantly

**But**: Still potential for misuse
rows.financialEmergency:
**Never tested**: Provisions exist but never used

**Concerns**:
• Vague grounds ('threat to financial stability' - subjective)
• No precedent or judicial interpretation
• Potential for misuse (reduce State salaries arbitrarily)
• Could be used for political pressure on States

rows.nationalEmergency:
**ADM Jabalpur v Shivkant Shukla (1976)**:
• During 1975 Emergency; SC held **no right to life/liberty** during emergency (Art 21 suspended)
• **Dissent by Justice H.R. Khanna**: Became celebrated dissent
• **Most criticized judgment** in SC history
• **Overruled implicitly**: 44th Amendment ensured Art 20-21 cannot be suspended

**Minerva Mills (1980)**:
• Struck down 42nd Amendment provisions extending emergency powers
rows.stateEmergency:
**S.R. Bommai v Union of India (1994)**:
• **Landmark 9-judge bench**
• **Federalism is basic structure** - Cannot be destroyed via Art 356
• President's satisfaction **justiciable** - Courts can examine
• **Floor test mandatory** - If majority dispute, prove on floor
• Governor's report not binding on President
• Parliament's approval also justiciable

**Effect**: Dramatically reduced Art 356 misuse post-1994
rows.financialEmergency:
**No case law**: Never proclaimed, never challenged

**No judicial precedent**

rows.nationalEmergency:
**1. Oct 1962**: China war (Indo-China war) - Lasted till Jan 1968

**2. Dec 1971**: Bangladesh war (Indo-Pakistan war) - Continued from 1971-77

**3. June 25, 1975**: **'The Emergency'** - Internal disturbance
• **Most infamous**: Indira Gandhi govt
• **21 months** (June 1975 - March 1977)
• Democracy suspended, press censored, opposition jailed
• **42nd Amendment** passed (Mini Constitution)
• Ended after Janata Party won 1977 elections
• **Dark chapter** in Indian democracy
rows.stateEmergency:
**First use**: Kerala 1959 (Communist govt dismissed)

**Most frequent**: 1977-79 (9 states after Emergency), 1980s-90s (frequent political dismissals)

**Notable**:
• Punjab 1987-92 (terrorism)
• J&K multiple times (1977, 1986, 1990, 1996, 2018)
• Bihar, UP, Uttarakhand, Arunachal Pradesh (recent)

**Post-Bommai**: Less frequent but still used (Uttarakhand 2016, Arunachal 2016)
rows.financialEmergency:
**NEVER proclaimed**

Not used even during:
• 1991 economic crisis (BOP crisis, forex depletion)
• 2008 global financial crisis
• 2020 COVID economic shock

**States never faced**: Even when States faced financial distress, Art 360 not invoked

rows.nationalEmergency:
**Most serious**: Affects entire country

**Federal → Unitary**: Parliament can legislate on State List, Union directs States

**FRs suspended**: Art 19 suspended (if war/external aggression); Art 20-21 protected

**Used 3 times**: 1962, 1971, **1975** (most controversial)

**44th Amendment safeguards**: Special majority, Cabinet advice in writing, Art 20-21 cannot be suspended
rows.stateEmergency:
**Most misused**: 125+ times; Often political

**State govt dismissed**: Parliament rules State; State Legislature dissolved/suspended

**No FR suspension**: FRs remain in force

**S.R. Bommai (1994)**: Curbed misuse; Federalism basic structure; Justiciable; Floor test

**Max 3 years**: 44th Amendment limit
rows.financialEmergency:
**Never used**: 0 times since 1950

**Financial control**: Union controls State finances; Can reduce salaries

**No FR suspension**: FRs remain in force

**No precedent**: Provisions untested; No case law

constitutionalBasis: **42nd Amendment 1976** (During Emergency): Strengthened emergency powers; Extended emergency provisions; Made Parliament supreme over judiciary
**44th Amendment 1978** (Post-Emergency): Restored balance; Added safeguards against misuse; Protected Art 20-21; Changed 'internal disturbance' to 'armed rebellion'
**Purpose**: Handle extraordinary situations threatening nation's security, integrity, or financial stability
rationaleBehindProvisions: **War/External threat**: Need quick, coordinated national response; State boundaries irrelevant in war
**Constitutional breakdown**: If State govt fails, Centre must intervene to maintain constitutional governance
**Financial crisis**: If economic collapse threatens nation, Centre needs control to restore stability
**Temporary measures**: All emergencies designed to be temporary; Restore normalcy ASAP
1975EmergencyDetails: **Reason**: 'Internal disturbance' (vague ground; Actually political - Allahabad HC had found Indira Gandhi guilty of election malpractice)
**Effects**: Press censorship, mass arrests (1 lakh+), opposition leaders jailed, judiciary weakened, Parliament rubber stamp
**Excesses**: Forced sterilization, demolitions, human rights violations
**42nd Amendment**: Passed during Emergency; 'Mini Constitution'; Extended Parliament/PM powers
**End**: Indira Gandhi called elections (March 1977); Janata Party won; Emergency revoked
**Legacy**: Dark chapter; Led to 44th Amendment safeguards; 'Never again' resolve
srBommaiImpact: **Before Bommai** (1947-1994): Art 356 used 90+ times; Frequent political misuse; Centre dismissed Opposition states routinely
**Bommai case** (1994): 9-judge bench; Federalism is basic structure; Justiciable; Floor test mandatory
**After Bommai** (1994-2024): Much less frequent; Judicial scrutiny; Political cost high; Used cautiously
**Impact**: Saved federalism; Protected State govts from arbitrary dismissal; Strengthened constitutional governance
financialEmergencyWhy NeverUsed: **Economic crises handled differently**: Fiscal policies, RBI intervention, IMF loans, structural reforms
**1991 crisis**: Severe BOP crisis, forex $1 billion; But handled through economic reforms (not Art 360)
**Political cost**: Proclaiming financial emergency = admitting govt failure; Heavy political cost
**State resistance**: States would strongly resist salary cuts, financial control
**Untested provision**: No precedent; Legal uncertainties; Risky to use first time
examTips: **Most asked**: 1975 Emergency details; 44th Amendment safeguards; S.R. Bommai case (Art 356)
**Comparison table**: Art 352 vs 356 vs 360 - Grounds, duration, effects, frequency
**44th Amendment**: Know all safeguards (special majority, written advice, Art 20-21 protected, LS disapproval)
**S.R. Bommai**: Federalism basic structure; Floor test; Justiciable - CRITICAL for Art 356
**1975 Emergency**: Timeline, causes, effects, excesses, end, legacy, 42nd Amendment
**Numbers**: Art 352 (3 times), Art 356 (125+ times), Art 360 (0 times)
**Never confuse**: National Emergency ≠ President's Rule; Different articles, effects, grounds

data.summary: **Three types of emergencies**: **(1) National Emergency (Art 352)** - War, External aggression, Armed rebellion; **Used 3 times** (1962 China war, 1971 Pakistan war, **1975 'The Emergency'**); Federal → Unitary; Parliament can legislate on State List; FRs suspended (Art 19 if war/external, Art 359 by Presidential order); **44th Amendment safeguards** - Special majority, Art 20-21 cannot be suspended, LS can disapprove. **(2) State Emergency/President's Rule (Art 356)** - Constitutional machinery failure in State; **Used 125+ times** (most misused); State govt dismissed, Parliament rules State; **S.R. Bommai (1994)** - Federalism basic structure, justiciable, floor test mandatory; Max 3 years. **(3) Financial Emergency (Art 360)** - Threat to financial stability; **NEVER used** (0 times); Union controls State finances, can reduce salaries. **1975 Emergency** = Darkest chapter (21 months, democracy suspended, press censored); Led to **44th Amendment 1978** (safeguards). **S.R. Bommai 1994** = Saved federalism (curbed Art 356 misuse).
